snippet.title: Multi-billion dollar value placed on Bayside property market - realestate.com.au
snippet.content:
With $74 billion, you could buy the $22 million luxury home at 39 Seacombe Grove, Brighton, 3363 times over.
How would you spend $74 billion dollars?
CoreLogic crunched the numbers for Bayside Leader, and if every property across the region were sold, there'd be about $74.095 billion to be made. The value was calculated by totalling the value of every property in each suburb. The values were generated through an automated valuation model that reflects the value of the property at that point in time, not just those sold recently. Homeowners might reap about $1.8 million if the entire region was sold, based on the 41,032 dwellings counted during the 2016 census. RELATED: RELATED: But rather than selling the whole thing, a few smart investments could be made. Brighton could be sold up, redefining Bayside's "Golden Mile" completely. Valued at about $26 million, it'd be a tempting offer for Jamaica, where the World Bank valued GDP at about $14.027 billion in 2016. Sandringham would bring in about $6.78 billion, which might catch Fiji's attention, where GDP was recorded as being $4.631 billion. RELATED: Kay & Burton Bayside senior sales consultant Bert Geraerts said the hefty figure surprised him. "It's everyone's goal to be Bayside though," Mr Geraerts said. "Demand keeps growing for Bayside property, and the market keeps going from strength to strength." Mr Geraerts said he believed values would continue to grow. "Particularly along the beach side of Nepean Highway, right down to Mordialloc," he said. Mr Geraerts said he believed most of the value would be tied up in Brighton's Golden Mile, as well as and .
